text:
So i was chatting to my son (A level maths student ) yesterday and talking through results.
We looked in depth at a couple of proven successful strategies and he said "Why not simply increase your stakes now dad"
We then had a chat about matching rates and adverse selection which brought him back to earth :thinking_face:
he countered by saying, "OK well why not setup a small account with a couple of hundred and set stakes as a percentage of balance (increase SLOWLY) and let it fly" Plot the P/L graph over time and at the point the profit line starts to exhibit a downtrend (ie diminishing returns) just before that may well be the optimum stakes.
Appreciate it not as sexy as doing backtests and detailed analysis, but would it fly or crash and burn!?

text: Hi Liam, yes I do have an element of AB testing as I have multiple versions of the same strategy and always comparing/contrasting anyway. The advantage of doing it as mentioned is that as you know, the stakes will increase/compound rapidly whenever you apply to a successful strategy. If the account stated with a small balance say £200, htat would be my maximum loss and i would be less worried about things when it stated throwing in large stakes. Stakes that I would not normally be comfortable with.  Now execution..that's a whole new ball game :grinning:

text: This seems to rely on the assumption that optimal stake size is a constant, which may be the case for some strategies but for others often optimal stake size is a function of some quantities that relate to market capacity. So your constant may only appear after normalizing by these quantities.
